data.title: Crafting a design system for a multiplanetary future
data.inti: Most companies try to stay ahead of the curve when it comes to visual design, but for Planetaria we needed to create a brand that would still inspire us 100 years from now when humanity has spread across our entire solar system.

data.title: Introducing Animaginary: High performance web animations
data.inti: When you’re building a website for a company as ambitious as Planetaria, you need to make an impression. I wanted people to visit our website and see animations that looked more realistic than reality itself.

data.title: Rewriting the cosmOS kernel in Rust
data.inti: When we released the first version of cosmOS last year, it was written in Go. Go is a wonderful programming language with a lot of benefits, but it’s been a while since I’ve seen an article on the front page of Hacker News about rewriting some important tool in Go and I see articles on there about rewriting things in Rust every single week.

data.name: Plannetaria
data.value: Creating technology to empower civilians to explore space on their own terms.

data.name: Animaginary
data.value: High performance web animation library, hand-written in optimized WASM.

data.name: HelioStream
data.value: Real-time video streaming library, optimized for interstellar transmission.

data.name: cosmOS
data.value: The operating system that powers our Planetaria space shuttles.

data.name: OpenShuttle
data.value: The schematics for the first rocket I designed that successfully made it to orbit.

data.name: In space, no one can watch you stream — until now
data.value: A technical deep-dive into HelioStream, the real-time streaming library I wrote for transmitting live video back to Earth.

data.name: Lessons learned from our first product recall
data.value: They say that if you’re not embarassed by your first version, you’re doing it wrong. Well when you’re selling DIY space shuttle kits it turns out it’s a bit more complicated.

data.name: Using design as a competitive advantage
data.value: How we used world-class visual design to attract a great team, win over customers, and get more press for Planetaria.

data.name: Bootstrapping an aerospace company to $17M ARR
data.value: The story of how we built one of the most promising space startups in the world without taking any capital from investors.

data.name: Programming your company operating system
data.value: On the importance of creating systems and processes for running your business so that everyone on the team knows how to make the right decision no matter the situation.

data.name: 16” MacBook Pro, M1 Max, 64GB RAM (2021)
data.value: I was using an Intel-based 16” MacBook Pro prior to this and the difference is night and day. I’ve never heard the fans turn on a single time, even under the incredibly heavy loads I put it through with our various launch simulations.

data.name: Apple Pro Display XDR (Standard Glass)
data.value: The only display on the market if you want something HiDPI and bigger than 27”. When you’re working at planetary scale, every pixel you can get counts.

data.name: IBM Model M SSK Industrial Keyboard
data.value: They don’t make keyboards the way they used to. I buy these any time I see them go up for sale and keep them in storage in case I need parts or need to retire my main.

data.name: Apple Magic Trackpad
data.value: Something about all the gestures makes me feel like a wizard with special powers. I really like feeling like a wizard with special powers.

data.name: Herman Miller Aeron Chair
data.value: If I’m going to slouch in the worst ergonomic position imaginable all day, I might as well do it in an expensive chair.

data.name: Sublime Text 4
data.value: I don’t care if it’s missing all of the fancy IDE features everyone else relies on, Sublime Text is still the best text editor ever made.

data.name: iTerm2
data.value: I’m honestly not even sure what features I get with this that aren’t just part of the macOS Terminal but it’s what I use.

data.name: TablePlus
data.value: Great software for working with databases. Has saved me from building about a thousand admin interfaces for my various projects over the years.

data.name: Figma
data.value: We started using Figma as just a design tool but now it’s become our virtual whiteboard for the entire company. Never would have expected the collaboration features to be the real hook.

data.name: Alfred
data.value: It’s not the newest kid on the block but it’s still the fastest. The Sublime Text of the application launcher world.

data.name: Reflect
data.value: Using a daily notes system instead of trying to keep things organized by topics has been super powerful for me. And with Reflect, it’s still easy for me to keep all of that stuff discoverable by topic even though all of my writing happens in the daily note.

data.name: SavvyCal
data.value: Great tool for scheduling meetings while protecting my calendar and making sure I still have lots of time for deep work during the week.

data.name: Focus
data.value: Simple tool for blocking distracting websites when I need to just do the work and get some momentum going.
